intro: Taeniophyllum leeuwenii, commonly known as the dwarf mistletoe, is a parasitic plant belonging to the Viscaraceae family. It typically grows on the branches of host trees, such as eucalyptus and acacia, in regions like Australia and New Zealand. The plant lacks true leaves and instead relies on its host for nutrients, using specialized structures called haustoria to absorb water and minerals. Its small, scale-like leaves and white or pink flowers are adapted for survival in its parasitic lifestyle. Taeniophyllum leeuwenii plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its host trees, influencing growth and sometimes causing dieback.
